awd_titl_txt: Superstring Theory, Gravitational Instantons and Black Hole Physics
awd_abstract_narration:
This award provides research travel support for Professor Wafic Sabra at the American University of Beirut, Lebanon.

The most pressing question in theoretical physics has been the reconciliation of the laws of quantum mechanics which govern the microscopic world of the very small with the theory of general relativity which governs the physics of gravity.   Another pressing question concerns the incorporation of gravity with the other fundamental forces of nature into a unified theory.   Einstein general relativity is sufficient to understand most gravitational phenomena, but quantum-mechanical corrections to this theory become important in the study of the early universe and the physics of black holes.  Professor Sabra will study the properties of the theories that might emerge from such a unified theory at lower energies.  This work might therefore have relevance for studies of black holes, particle physics, and cosmology.   The interdisciplinary nature of this research makes it potentially valuable to both physicists and mathematicians.    This grant will also help to support theoretical physics at the American University of Beirut, a leading University promoting the American liberal-arts system in Lebanon and the Middle East.  It will also encourage students there to actively engage in high-energy physics research, still an underdeveloped field in this part of the world. 

More specifically, Professor Sabra will conduct research in the construction of Lorentzian and Euclidean supergravity theories and the study and analysis of their supersymmetric and non-supersymmetric gravitational solutions. In the classification of supersymmetric solutions, i.e., solutions admitting Killing spinors, he will use the powerful method of spinorial geometry.  He will also classify gravitational instantons and study their connections with integrable models, Einstein--Weyl structures and black holes in higher dimensions.  He will also explore the interpretation of Euclidean supergravity solutions in terms of string and M-theory.

por.por_cntn:
After the successful unification of the electro-weak and strong force within the standard model, the most pressing question in theoretical physics has since been the reconciliation of quantum mechanics with Einstein theory of general relativity, as well as the incorporation of quantum gravity with the other fundamental forces in a unified theory. Classically, all gravitational phenomena can be analyzed using the general theory of relativity. However, in the study of the early universe and black hole physics, quantum effects become very significant and can not be ignored. Superstring theory emerged as a very promising approach to the unification of fundamental forces including gravity. Initially, it appeared that there are five consistent superstring theories, all living in ten space-time dimensions. However, more recently, a new picture has emerged pointing to the existence of a fundamental eleven-dimensional theory, the M-theory. The five distinct superstring theories are nothing but different perturbative expansions of M-theory. Moreover, a novel holographic duality was discovered which relates quantum physics in d-dimensions to classical gravitational dynamics in d+1-dimensions.
    The main focus of our research is on understanding the basic laws that govern the fundamental forces in nature, developing our understanding of various stringy dualities and their implication to the yet unknown non-perturbative structure underlying string theory and black hole physics, and incorporating the new developments in the study of the phenomenological implications of string theory to gravitational physics, particle physics and cosmology.
     We were successful in the construction of large families of new supersymmetric solutions to supergravity theories in various space-time dimensions and signatures descending from the grand M-theory. We have established novel relations between black hole physics, complex geometry and integrable models and developed new links between pure mathematics and theoretical physics. Time-dependent cosmological and static gravitational solutions related to Kasner and Melvin solutions as well as flux-branes and domain walls were obtained.
    Our discovered solutions have potential applications to cosmology and the AdS/CFT correspondence. They are not only relevant to the development of particle, gravitational physics and cosmology but also are very important to the development of the fields of gauge theories and the study of duality symmetries in string and M-theory. Our results are of relevance to both Mathematics and Theoretical Physics communities. In particular, they will have an impact on the fields of differential geometry, differential equations, integrable systems, particle physics, black hole and gravitational physics.
